with more modern cities during
his World War II service with the
US Army.
One of his
major jobs was to revive the
University of Rome as a leading
institution following years of
Fascist domination.
In appreciation for his services,
the Italian government made
Rowell a Knight Officer of the
Crown.

Orientation selections extended three days
By CAROL TRZCINSKI
A poor turnout of applicants
at the interviews held Wednesday
night for the position of
Orientation Chairperson has led
to a three day extension of the
selections process according to
Selections Committee Chairman
Bob Lewin.

Bob Lewin

The interviews will continue
over the next day or so in order
that the Committee be able to
make contact with all five people
who had expressed interest in
applying for the position. Lewin
stated that only two of those
showed for the interviews
Wednesday.
The committee will have
several factors to consider when
reviewing the qualifications of
each candidate.
Lewin explained that some of
this year's applicants had been
involved in a workshop
sponsored earlier in the year 1;;,^
the Union, under the direction of
Alan Sapakie. According to
Lewin, the six to seven week
session with an "Orientation
guy" from Cornell has given
some applicants time and
exposure to thinking about the
problems of Orientation, thereby
providing them a stronger base
grom which to voice their ideas
for the fall event.
It's the type of thing where,by
talking about Orientation for six
or seven weeks, they've gained
some expertise in the area."
Lewin commented.
The senior blamed pool

publicity of the workshop for the
lack of attendence exhibited by
most of the Orientation
applicants.
"Most of the people I asked
said that they just hadn't known
about the workshops," Lewin
continued.
"Ignorance is certainly a valid
excuse in this case as I feel that
the project didn't receive enough
publicity."
Lewin also cited the
"Head-on" competition that had
developed between membersof
the original workshop who had
since decided to apply for the
position. Two of the seven
workshop attendents are involved
in the selection.
Lewin stressed that objectivity
would be maintained on his part
despite the circumstances that
had evolved out of the workshop
series. He also expressed hope
that the other members of the
Selections Committee would
hold as objective a viewpoint as
possible under the circumstances.
"The position should be open
to the student body and not just
ot those who attended the
workshops," Lewin asserted.
"EAch applicant will be

looked at as anyone else."
Another issue that the SC
Chairman and his Committee
members will have to contend
with is the situation of having
one of its members applying for
thee position on whichshe will
have a deciding vote.
"Shep Hoffman and I brought
up the issue that Sue Matson
consider resigning from the
SElections Committee at last
Tuesday's SC meeting,"
continued Lewin.
"I was concerned over the
credibility of the Council if they
backed any member who pursued
a student position during their
SC term. At last Tuesday's
meeting, everyone backed her
100%."
As for last fall's Orientation,
Lewin stated that the Union had
felt "too many hass1;,ss behind the
scenes" and complained of an
overall lack of organization,
though execution of the
week-long activities went
relatively well.
Lewin stated that Sapakie had
expressed concern over the
distribution of authority and felt
that "not enough people had
gotten involved in Orientation."

He accused George S. Benton,
Vice-President for Homewood
Divisions and chairman of the
Energy Committee, of "using the
committee as a rubber stamp for
his own policies." He added,
"Every one on the committee is
being abused."
Shep Hoffmann, Senior Class
President, pointed out that any
University closing was a de facto
increase in tuition for the
Hopkins student population."We
are not prepared to sanction a
shutdown to save the University
money," he declared and SAvitz
promptly seconded him.
Later these concerns gave way
to the fear, expressed by Bob
Lewin, Selections Committee
chairman, that the selection of
Susan Matson, Junior Class
representative, as Orientation
chairman for next fall would
expose her and the Selections
Committee of which she is a
member to charges of conflicting
interst, and favoritism.

her position on the Committee,
"smelling not like a rose but with

and appeared reluctant to leave
the Selections Committee. Most
Student Council members saw
little reason to dispute her. Ben

interest in presenting a topic for
the Eisenhower Symposium. The
same point was not lost on

John Colmers, Vice-President , to
preside over the rest of the
discussion.
The question was in the end
left to the Selections Committee
itself to decide.
